article.title: China DRAM Maker CXMT Targets $4.2B IPO as It Takes on Samsung, SK Hynix, Micron

summary: Chinese DRAM manufacturer ChangXin Memory Technologies (CXMT) has filed for a $4.2 billion IPO on Shanghai's STAR Market, aiming to boost its capacity and technology to challenge global leaders Samsung, SK Hynix, and Micron. The move underscores China's strategic push to develop a self-reliant, competitive domestic memory chip industry amid a market dominated by a few global players.

rewrite.title: China’s CXMT Files $4.2B IPO to Rival Global DRAM Giants
rewrite.body:
ChangXin Memory Technologies Group (CXMT), China’s leading DRAM manufacturer, officially submitted its prospectus for a $4.2 billion initial public offering on the Shanghai STAR Market on December 30, 2025. Sponsored by state-backed CICC and CSC Financial, the IPO proceeds will fund capacity expansion, process technology upgrades, and next-generation DRAM research. This capital raise is a strategic step to strengthen CXMT’s position in a market long dominated by Samsung, SK Hynix, and Micron.

Founded in 2016, CXMT has rapidly grown to become China’s largest and fourth-largest global DRAM producer, capturing nearly 4% of the worldwide market as of Q2 2025. The company’s product lineup includes DDR4, DDR5, LPDDR4X, and LPDDR5/5X memory chips, with its latest LPDDR5X achieving speeds up to 10,667 Mbps—significantly narrowing the technology gap with global leaders. Operating three 12-inch fabs in Hefei and Beijing, CXMT is vertically integrated across R&D, design, and fabrication.

Financially, CXMT has seen robust revenue growth, generating approximately CNY 57 billion (~$8.16 billion) from 2022 through mid-2025. However, it remains unprofitable due to heavy investments in capacity and R&D, with cumulative net losses exceeding CNY 40.86 billion (~$5.85 billion). The company anticipates a turnaround in 2025, projecting revenues between CNY 55 billion and 58 billion and a net profit of up to CNY 3.5 billion, driven by surging AI-related memory demand and a tightening DRAM supply environment.

Notably, CXMT’s IPO is the first accepted under China’s new STAR Market pre-review mechanism for firms developing critical core technologies, expediting the listing process while safeguarding sensitive information. With a diversified shareholder base including state-backed funds and tech giants like Alibaba and Tencent, CXMT’s public debut marks a significant milestone in China’s ambition to build a globally competitive semiconductor memory ecosystem, potentially reshaping the industry’s competitive landscape.
